beats.label: ZONE 1: Mile 200
beats.narration: Mile 200. Mitchell, Oregon (CP1). First checkpoint. Eastern Oregon is dry and sparse. services thin, carry extra water. Psychological transition from coast to interior.

beats.label: ZONE 2: Mile 800
beats.narration: Mile 800. Montana/Wyoming. Rocky Mountain crossings begin. Near Yellowstone/Grand Teton. Beautiful but demanding elevation. Lander to Rawlins has sparse services.
beats.visual: Route map with zone marker animation

beats.label: ZONE 3: Mile 1400
beats.narration: Mile 1400. Hoosier Pass, Colorado. Highest point at 12 thousand feet. Major psychological milestone. Altitude affects everyone. Snow possible any time.
beats.visual: Route map with zone marker animation

broll_sources.query: Trans Am Bike Race course preview

beats.editing_note: Zone marker 3 appears on map. Progressive color intensity (green→yellow→red).

beats.label: ZONE 4: Mile 2200
beats.narration: Mile 2200. Kansas Plains. The great mental test. 400+ miles of relentless wind, endless horizon, and psychological monotony. Flat in profile but brutal in execution. Has ended more Trans Am attempts than any mountain.
beats.visual: Route map with zone marker animation

broll_sources.query: Trans Am Bike Race course preview
gravel cycling Primarily paved roads following the historic TransAmerica Bicycle Trail

beats.editing_note: Zone marker 4 appears on map. Progressive color intensity (green→yellow→red).

beats.label: ZONE 5: Mile 3500
beats.narration: Mile 3500. Appalachian Mountains. Final 700 miles have 15 thousand feet MORE climbing than first 1.1 thousand miles through Rockies. Steep, punchy, roller-coaster grades when you're already destroyed. Virginia has the most total elevation gain of any state.
